Literature Review: Electroporation technologies have experienced significant advancements over the past decade, transforming from benchtop applications to clinical settings. The underlying biophysics of electroporation involves the application of an electric field to create temporary pores in cell membranes, allowing for the efficient transfer of molecules across the cell boundary (1). This phenomenon has been extensively studied in molecular biology for its potential in transfecting mammalian and bacterial cells (2), as well as for food sanitation (3). In therapeutic settings, electroporation has been utilized to enhance drug uptake, facilitate gene therapy, and eliminate cancerous tissues (4, 5). The increasing adoption of electroporation-based technologies has led to an expansion of clinical research initiatives, with emerging applications in in vivo settings (6). This review aims to discuss the recent advancements in electroporation technologies, from nano- and microscale single-cell electroporation to emerging in vivo applications, and to highlight the biophysics required for understanding the cell permeation phenomenon that is electroporation.
